position.marginalia_text: Refert Gra[e]cum Epigramma, Bacchum aliquando cu[m] Venere concubuisse, ex eoq[ue] coitu Podagram filia[m] genuisse.

marginalia.translation: The Greek record the epigram that sometime Bacchus slept with Venus, and that from that intercourse the daughter Podagra was born.

position.marginalia_text: Therapeutica: pra[e]sertim podagra[e]. An hoc remedio caruerunt Baconus, custos magni sigilli: et Cecilius, Anglia[e] thesaurarius? duo prudentiss[im]i

marginalia.translation: Therapist: especially of podagra. Can it be that Nicolas Bacon, Keeper of the Great Seal, and William Cecil, the English treasurer, are without this remedy? Two most prudent and delightful men.

position.marginalia_text: Alacres, atq[ue] la[e]ti sermones; solatio pleni, ualdeq[ue] cordiales.

marginalia.translation: Cheerful and happy speeches; for the comfort of many, and greatly affectionate.

position.marginalia_text: Remedia aliquot Podagra[e]. Podagra, vitium est articuloru[m] in pedibus: sicuti chiragra in manibus. à

dicit[u]r gra[e]cè. vnde podager, et chirager, et podagricus, et chiragricus. maximu[m] enim iste morbus dolorem infligit. Perrarò autem, uel castratos; uel pueros, ante foeminae coitum; uel mulieres, nisi suppressis menstruis, tentat. fera. ouidius. Soluere nodosam nescit medicina Podagram. 1. At quidam, cum Asinino laite epoto sese eluissent, in perpetuum hoc malum euaserunt. perottus.} Quida[m] asininu[m] lac bibendo, podagra, chiragraue prorsus liberati fuisse legu[n]tur. Perottus. Ide[m] alio loco. 2. Alij cum toto anno à igno mulso, venereq[ue] sibi temperassent; ait Sipontinus Pontifex; totius vita[e] securitatem sunt adepti. 3. M. Agrippa, supremis a[e]tatis sua[e] annis hoc morbo grauiter conflictatus, cum perpeti ampliùs tantu[m] dolorem non posset, media cuiusda[m] portentoso confilio, ignorante id Diuo Augusto, in acetum calidum crura dimersit; sicq[ue] in totum liberatus est. 4. Sextus Pompeius Hispania[e] citerioris Princeps, cum horreis suis uentilandis pra[e]sideret, correptus Podagra[e] dolore sese in triticum super genua dimisit, leuatusqu[e] miru[m] in modu[m] dolore, pedibus ita siccatis hoc posteà remedio vsus est. 5. Vrtica herba, ab urendo dicta, quòd folia eius tacta acerrimè vrant, vtilissima est in cibis cocta, conditaue, lieni, duritia[e] uentris, intestinis animaliu[m], articularibus, et podagricis morbis, arteria[e], tussi, uentris distillationi, panis, id est inguinu[m] tumoribus, parotidi, id est apostemati secu[n]du[m] aurem, pernionibus, id est morbis pedu[m] ex nimio frigore prouenientibus, et calcaneu[m] pra[e]cipuè infestantibus. Auctor Phanias physicus. Constat, ait Perottus, si quis decocto vrtica[e] pedes hyeme lauauerit, eo die no[n] frigescere. Quida[m] scripsit

Pectus pra[e]tereà purgat, vrina[m] ciet, sanguine[m] nariu[m] sistit, calculos rumpit, uuam reprimit. Eodem auctore. Rapu[m] domesticu[m] perniones feruens impositu[m] sanat; et crudum tusum, cu[m] sale, prodest cuicumq[ue] uitjo Pedum. Plinius. dictu[m], q[uo]d passim rapiatum. 6. Axungia, ab axe uehiculorum plaustrorum unguendo appellata, sanat podagras, ambusta, perniones, confricata membra: item lassitudines, et fatigationes leuat: prodest etia[m] tussi ueteri: Phtisi in catapocijs, hoc est pilsulis sumpta: contra scabiem. Perottus.

marginalia.translation:
Some remedies of gout. Gout is a defect of the joints in the feet; just as arthritis in the hands. From [GREEK] and [GREEK], and with the dreadfulness of pain, which is said to be grave. From where gout and arthritis, and gout-suffers and those having arthritis. For this disease inflict the greatest pain. But very rarely it attacks either castrated men, boys, before the sexual intercourse with women, or women, unless after having suppressed menstruation. Uncivilised. Ovid. Treatment does not know how to loosen knots of gout.
1. But certain people had cleared themselves with drinking mild of a donkey [and] completely avoided this evil. } Certain people were gathering that, by dinking the mild of a donkey, they were freed entirely from gout and arthritis. Niccolo Perotti. The same in another place. 2. Others had relieved themselves by stroking inflamed [joints] and by elegance for a whole year, said the archbishop of Sipontinus [= Niccolo Perotti]. They gained security for their whole life. 3. Marcus Agrippa, gravely afflicted by this disease in the last periods of his life, since he could not endure much more pain, by a common omen of a certain person , the holy emporor unaware of this, he dipped the leg into hot vinegar; and thus he was healed completely. 4. Sextus Pompeius, the leader of 'Nearer Spain' (Hispania Citerior), with its barns exposed to draught he presided over, seized by the pain of gout, sent himself away into the weath above the knee, and relieved from the pain in this wonderful way, he thus used this remedy for this exhausted feet afterwards. 5. Stinging nettle, named after its burning, because its leaves burn most fiercely when touched, is most useful digested in food, if you will seasoned with spleen, for the hardness of the stomach, with the intestines of animals, for the joints and gout, for the artery, for the cough, for the fluid of the stomach, for thread wounds, that is, for the turmors of the groins, for tumours near the ear, that is following the ear to the abcess, for chilblains, that is for diseases of the feet coming forth from excessive cold, and especially from infestations of the heels. The author is Phanias Physicus. It is well known, Perroti says, that if anyone relieved the feet with boiled [leaves] of the sting nettle in winter, he would not get cold that day. A certain [Greek] [translation of pelli based on Greek words] wrote [that he] drove out, if a body was rubbed over with these methods. Joachim Fortius Ringelberg in 'Experiments'. In addition, it purges the heart, discharges the urine, stops a nosebleed, destroys bladder stones, checks a grape. By the same author. A warm domestic turnip cures the inflicted chilblain; and crudely pulped with salt it is useful for every defect of the feet. Pliny. The maxim which everywhere [...] 6. Animal fat, named after the greased axe of vehicles, rubbed over limbs, cures gout, burns, chilblains; likewise it relieves exhaustion and weariness. It even is useful for chronic coughs. For a lung disease in pills, this is obtain in against itches. Perroti.
